[1] Nitric oxide (NO) plays a key role in many physiological and pathophysiological events, including the control of cell respiration. [2] Both reversible and irreversible inhibition of mitochondrial respiration have been reported following the generation of NO by cells. [3] We have exposed the murine macrophage cell line J774 to high concentrations of NO, such as are generated in some pathological conditions, and determined their effect on oxygen consumption. [4] We observed a persistent inhibition of respiration which was due to a redox-dependent, progressive inhibition of complex I activity.
